core_meaning.legge_1899_public_domain: Kh wei indicates that, (notwithstanding the condition of things which it denotes), in small matters there will (still) be good success.
core_meaning.normalized_summary: Estrangement. People’s aims and loyalties are out of sync, so large unified action is not possible. But you can still find workable, honest collaboration in specific, limited contexts. The strategy is: don’t panic, don’t force total agreement, and don’t lash out in paranoia — instead, meet quietly, build trust in small ways, and let misunderstanding soften.

translations.text: The first NINE, undivided, shows that (to its subject) occasion for repentance will disappear. He has lost his horses, but let him not seek for them;--they will return of themselves. Should he meet with bad men, he will not err (in communicating with them).
初九：悔亡，喪馬勿逐，自復；見惡人，無咎。

lines.normalized_meaning: Regret fades. What’s gone will come back on its own — no chasing. You can even engage with people you consider ‘bad’ without harm, as long as you stay clear and don’t escalate.

translations.text: The second NINE, undivided, shows its subject happening to meet with his lord in a bye-passage. There will be no error.

lines.normalized_meaning: A quiet, offstage meeting with real authority. Loyalty is recognized in private, not ceremony. This low-profile contact is blameless.

translations.text: In the third SIX, divided, we see one whose carriage is dragged back, while the oxen in it are pushed back, and he is himself subjected to the shaving of his head and the cutting off of his nose. There is no good beginning, but there will be a good end.
六三：見輿曳，其牛掣，其人天且劓，無初有終。

lines.normalized_meaning: You’re stopped, humiliated, punished. The start is ugly. But if you endure, the end can still come out right.

translations.text: The fourth NINE, undivided, shows its subject solitary amidst the (prevailing) disunion. (But) he meets with the good man (represented by the first line), and they blend their sincere desires together. The position is one of peril, but there will be no mistake.
九四：睽孤，遇元夫，交孚，厲無咎。

lines.normalized_meaning: You feel alone in a divided time, then you meet a true ally. You unify intentions honestly. It’s dangerous, but if the bond is sincere, there’s no blame.

translations.text: The fifth SIX, divided, shows that (to its subject) occasion for repentance will disappear. With his relative (and minister he unites closely and readily) as if he were biting through a piece of skin. When he goes forward (with this help), what error can there be?
六五：悔亡，厥宗噬膚，往何咎。

lines.normalized_meaning: You close ranks with someone deeply trusted — kin / true minister. The connection is immediate and effortless, like biting through thin skin. Moving ahead together clears regret.

translations.text: The topmost NINE, undivided, shows its subject solitary amidst the (prevailing) disunion. (In the subject of the third line, he seems to) see a pig bearing on its back a load of mud, (or fancies) there is a carriage full of ghosts. He first bends his bow against him, and afterwards unbends it, (for he discovers) that he is not an assailant to injure, but a near relative. Going forward, he shall meet with (genial) rain, and there will be good fortune.
上九：睽孤，見豕負塗，載鬼一車，先張之弧，後說之弧，匪寇婚媾，往遇雨則吉。

lines.normalized_meaning: When you feel cut off, you start seeing threats everywhere — filthy pigs, ghosts, attackers. You almost shoot. Then you realize it’s not an enemy, it’s kin. Misunderstanding dissolves like welcome rain, and fortune returns.
